LIFE752
Notes
Change in staffing:
Prof Daniel Rigden has been teaching different aspects of computational prediction of protein structure and interaction across three different PG modules (LIFE721, LIFE748 and LIFE752).

As the new MO for LIFE752, Francesco Del Carratore wishes to teach in this module. After discussing with the rest of the teaching staff, he concluded that the best course of action would be for him to substitute Prof Ridgen in this module as he will expand his material within the other two modules he is teaching, hence avoiding any loss for the students.

Within LIFE752, Francesco will teach genome-scale metabolic models (an extremely relevant topic in computational biology that will strongly benefit the students). This means that the topic 4 currently listed in the syllabus (covariance-based prediction of protein structure and interaction) will not be covered, therefore it will need to be changed to ‘genome-scale metabolic models’.

It is also paramount that the assessment associated with this new material is fit for purpose. This new material should be assessed within assessment 2, which is currently described as a literature critique, which will be too demanding for students that are introduced to this type of mathematical modelling for the first time.
Shifting to a scientific report will allow the students to be assessed on the understanding of a very simple toy model thoroughly explained during the lectures and workshop.

This has been discussed with Dr Savage and Dr Jorgensen as the topics they are teaching are also assessed in assessment 1, and they both agreed that the proposed change would also strongly improve their assessment.

There have been no further changes to the assessments or LOs.

Overview

Overview
Biologists and clinicians are increasingly making use of complex genomic data sets to understand fundamental biological processes, and to reconstruct the history of organisms and disease outbreaks. The aim of this course is to equip students with a broad understanding of these kinds of data and their analyses, and to develop insight into how these methods can be applied to answer biological and medical questions.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The primary teaching will be done through workshops, which will provide basic background knowledge in the topic and types of analyses, coupled with practical exercises involving analyses of example data sets. Lectures will provide an in-depth, research-connected teaching background to selected topics.

The module will be assessed via two scientific reports. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:
1.To support students develop a comprehensive understanding of complex computational approaches
2.Enable students to identify the correct computational approach to address a wide range of biological questions.
Marketing Module Synopsis
With the advent of genomics and functional genomics, biology has become a quantitative data-rich discipline. This has created unprecedented opportunities in virtually every area of life sciences. With the right tools, it is now possible to address fundamentally important biological questions simply analysing already available datasets. This module is designed to prepare students for this very challenge. The module covers the most important aspects of computational biology. These range from the analysis of large datasets to infer biological mechanisms to the use of mathematical modelling to conceptualize and simulate complex biological phenomena. In addition to providing an intuitive overview of the basic theoretical principles, the module will focus on real life applications through multiple cases studies. Among these, students will learn how to identify drug targets and mechanisms of drug resistance and how to understand mathematical models of biological systems. They will then learn aspects of quantitative system pharmacology and physiologically based pharmacokinetic modelling pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic modelling.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures, workshops and seminars. The module will be assessed via two written reports.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1
Introduction to computational biology. Overall description of approaches of computational biology with a strategic vision for the interplay between different languages and biological fields.

Topic 2
Introduction to R. Introducing programming in R including input/output of data, data types, wrangling data and producing basic plots. Introducing data-driven biology with examples and case studies in different areas that highlight the importance of data integration, needed skills and enhance critical thinking

Topic 3
Mathematical modelling as a tool for understanding biological mechanisms. Overview of mathematical approaches and examples of applications

Topic 4
Genome-scale metabolic models. Application of network-based tools that collect metabolic information of a biological system, including the genes, enzymes, reactions, associated gene-protein-reaction rules, and metabolites.

Topic 5
Computational pharmacology. Application of multiple computational approaches for the discovery of novel therapeutic agents and the optimisation of existing therapies.

Topic 6
Pharmacogenomics and Personalised Medicine. Overview of methods for identifying genome-wide variants influencing treatment response, and for developing prediction models for personalised medicine.

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lectures: These will cover core curriculum topics. Research focus lectures will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area.

Attendance Recorded: yes

During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. These comprise of multiple sessions of active learning which focus on the assessment tasks/real world research, data analysis and simulations. Typically, the workshop will run after the lecture, helping to consolidate and practice theoretical learning.

Attendance Recorded: yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module. The workshops approach was designed to promote students’ active learning by practicing key computational skills and actively engage in discussions exercising their communication skills.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments. Both assessments are authentic. Writing scientifically in the format of a report is clearly valuable but using real datasets and scenarios to answer real world issues allows students to consider why that task matters. This enables a shift from working in isolation to becoming a member of society and provides a sense of achievement and self-worth.

The first assessment is a piece of data analysis coursework, based on tasks related to the different topics. It is worth 50% of the module.

The second assessment will consist of a scientific report on topics covered in the module. It is worth 50% of the module.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%.

Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given to the assessment and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 50% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

2.Enable students to identify the correct computational approach to address a wide range of biological questions.
Marketing Module Synopsis
With the advent of genomics and functional genomics, biology has become a quantitative data-rich discipline. This has created unprecedented opportunities in virtually every area of life sciences. With the right tools, it is now possible to address fundamentally important biological questions simply analysing already available datasets. This module is designed to prepare students for this very challenge. The module covers the most important aspects of computational biology. These range from the analysis of large datasets to infer biological mechanisms to the use of mathematical modelling to conceptualize and simulate complex biological phenomena. In addition to providing an intuitive overview of the basic theoretical principles, the module will focus on real life applications through multiple cases studies. Among these, students will learn how to identify drug targets and mechanisms of drug resistance and how to understand mathematical models of biological systems. They will then learn aspects of quantitative system pharmacology and physiologically based pharmacokinetic modelling pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic modelling.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures, workshops and seminars. The module will be assessed via two written reports.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1
Introduction to computational biology. Overall description of approaches of computational biology with a strategic vision for the interplay between different languages and biological fields.

Topic 2
Introduction to R. Introducing programming in R including input/output of data, data types, wrangling data and producing basic plots. Introducing data-driven biology with examples and case studies in different areas that highlight the importance of data integration, needed skills and enhance critical thinking

Topic 3
Mathematical modelling as a tool for understanding biological mechanisms. Overview of mathematical approaches and examples of applications

Topic 4
Genome-scale metabolic models. Application of network-based tools that collect metabolic information of a biological system, including the genes, enzymes, reactions, associated gene-protein-reaction rules, and metabolites.

Topic 5
Computational pharmacology. Application of multiple computational approaches for the discovery of novel therapeutic agents and the optimisation of existing therapies.

Topic 6
Pharmacogenomics and Personalised Medicine. Overview of methods for identifying genome-wide variants influencing treatment response, and for developing prediction models for personalised medicine.

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lectures: These will cover core curriculum topics. Research focus lectures will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area.

Attendance Recorded: yes

During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. These comprise of multiple sessions of active learning which focus on the assessment tasks/real world research, data analysis and simulations. Typically, the workshop will run after the lecture, helping to consolidate and practice theoretical learning.

Attendance Recorded: yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module. The workshops approach was designed to promote students’ active learning by practicing key computational skills and actively engage in discussions exercising their communication skills.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments. Both assessments are authentic. Writing scientifically in the format of a report is clearly valuable but using real datasets and scenarios to answer real world issues allows students to consider why that task matters. This enables a shift from working in isolation to becoming a member of society and provides a sense of achievement and self-worth.

The first assessment is a piece of data analysis coursework, based on tasks related to the different topics. It is worth 50% of the module.

The second assessment will consist of a scientific report on topics covered in the module. It is worth 50% of the module.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%.

Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given to the assessment and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 50% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

LIFE752
Notes
Change in staffing:
Prof Daniel Rigden has been teaching different aspects of computational prediction of protein structure and interaction across three different PG modules (LIFE721, LIFE748 and LIFE752).

As the new MO for LIFE752, Francesco Del Carratore wishes to teach in this module. After discussing with the rest of the teaching staff, he concluded that the best course of action would be for him to substitute Prof Ridgen in this module as he will expand his material within the other two modules he is teaching, hence avoiding any loss for the students.

Within LIFE752, Francesco will teach genome-scale metabolic models (an extremely relevant topic in computational biology that will strongly benefit the students). This means that the topic 4 currently listed in the syllabus (covariance-based prediction of protein structure and interaction) will not be covered, therefore it will need to be changed to ‘genome-scale metabolic models’.

It is also paramount that the assessment associated with this new material is fit for purpose. This new material should be assessed within assessment 2, which is currently described as a literature critique, which will be too demanding for students that are introduced to this type of mathematical modelling for the first time.
Shifting to a scientific report will allow the students to be assessed on the understanding of a very simple toy model thoroughly explained during the lectures and workshop.

This has been discussed with Dr Savage and Dr Jorgensen as the topics they are teaching are also assessed in assessment 1, and they both agreed that the proposed change would also strongly improve their assessment.

There have been no further changes to the assessments or LOs.

Overview

Overview
Biologists and clinicians are increasingly making use of complex genomic data sets to understand fundamental biological processes, and to reconstruct the history of organisms and disease outbreaks. The aim of this course is to equip students with a broad understanding of these kinds of data and their analyses, and to develop insight into how these methods can be applied to answer biological and medical questions.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The primary teaching will be done through workshops, which will provide basic background knowledge in the topic and types of analyses, coupled with practical exercises involving analyses of example data sets. Lectures will provide an in-depth, research-connected teaching background to selected topics.

The module will be assessed via two scientific reports. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:
1.To support students develop a comprehensive understanding of complex computational approaches
2.Enable students to identify the correct computational approach to address a wide range of biological questions.

Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given to the assessment and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 50% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes
Change in staffing:
Prof Daniel Rigden has been teaching different aspects of computational prediction of protein structure and interaction across three different PG modules (LIFE721, LIFE748 and LIFE752).

As the new MO for LIFE752, Francesco Del Carratore wishes to teach in this module. After discussing with the rest of the teaching staff, he concluded that the best course of action would be for him to substitute Prof Ridgen in this module as he will expand his material within the other two modules he is teaching, hence avoiding any loss for the students.

Within LIFE752, Francesco will teach genome-scale metabolic models (an extremely relevant topic in computational biology that will strongly benefit the students). This means that the topic 4 currently listed in the syllabus (covariance-based prediction of protein structure and interaction) will not be covered, therefore it will need to be changed to ‘genome-scale metabolic models’.

It is also paramount that the assessment associated with this new material is fit for purpose. This new material should be assessed within assessment 2, which is currently described as a literature critique, which will be too demanding for students that are introduced to this type of mathematical modelling for the first time.
Shifting to a scientific report will allow the students to be assessed on the understanding of a very simple toy model thoroughly explained during the lectures and workshop.

This has been discussed with Dr Savage and Dr Jorgensen as the topics they are teaching are also assessed in assessment 1, and they both agreed that the proposed change would also strongly improve their assessment.

There have been no further changes to the assessments or LOs.

Overview

Overview
Biologists and clinicians are increasingly making use of complex genomic data sets to understand fundamental biological processes, and to reconstruct the history of organisms and disease outbreaks. The aim of this course is to equip students with a broad understanding of these kinds of data and their analyses, and to develop insight into how these methods can be applied to answer biological and medical questions.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The primary teaching will be done through workshops, which will provide basic background knowledge in the topic and types of analyses, coupled with practical exercises involving analyses of example data sets. Lectures will provide an in-depth, research-connected teaching background to selected topics.

The module will be assessed via two scientific reports. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:
1.To support students develop a comprehensive understanding of complex computational approaches
2.Enable students to identify the correct computational approach to address a wide range of biological questions.
Marketing Module Synopsis
With the advent of genomics and functional genomics, biology has become a quantitative data-rich discipline. This has created unprecedented opportunities in virtually every area of life sciences. With the right tools, it is now possible to address fundamentally important biological questions simply analysing already available datasets. This module is designed to prepare students for this very challenge. The module covers the most important aspects of computational biology. These range from the analysis of large datasets to infer biological mechanisms to the use of mathematical modelling to conceptualize and simulate complex biological phenomena. In addition to providing an intuitive overview of the basic theoretical principles, the module will focus on real life applications through multiple cases studies. Among these, students will learn how to identify drug targets and mechanisms of drug resistance and how to understand mathematical models of biological systems. They will then learn aspects of quantitative system pharmacology and physiologically based pharmacokinetic modelling pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic modelling.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures, workshops and seminars. The module will be assessed via two written reports.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1
Introduction to computational biology. Overall description of approaches of computational biology with a strategic vision for the interplay between different languages and biological fields.

Topic 2
Introduction to R. Introducing programming in R including input/output of data, data types, wrangling data and producing basic plots. Introducing data-driven biology with examples and case studies in different areas that highlight the importance of data integration, needed skills and enhance critical thinking

Topic 3
Mathematical modelling as a tool for understanding biological mechanisms. Overview of mathematical approaches and examples of applications

Topic 4
Genome-scale metabolic models. Application of network-based tools that collect metabolic information of a biological system, including the genes, enzymes, reactions, associated gene-protein-reaction rules, and metabolites.

Topic 5
Computational pharmacology. Application of multiple computational approaches for the discovery of novel therapeutic agents and the optimisation of existing therapies.

Topic 6
Pharmacogenomics and Personalised Medicine. Overview of methods for identifying genome-wide variants influencing treatment response, and for developing prediction models for personalised medicine.

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lectures: These will cover core curriculum topics. Research focus lectures will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area.

Attendance Recorded: yes

During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. These comprise of multiple sessions of active learning which focus on the assessment tasks/real world research, data analysis and simulations. Typically, the workshop will run after the lecture, helping to consolidate and practice theoretical learning.

Attendance Recorded: yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module. The workshops approach was designed to promote students’ active learning by practicing key computational skills and actively engage in discussions exercising their communication skills.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments. Both assessments are authentic. Writing scientifically in the format of a report is clearly valuable but using real datasets and scenarios to answer real world issues allows students to consider why that task matters. This enables a shift from working in isolation to becoming a member of society and provides a sense of achievement and self-worth.

The first assessment is a piece of data analysis coursework, based on tasks related to the different topics. It is worth 50% of the module.

The second assessment will consist of a scientific report on topics covered in the module. It is worth 50% of the module.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%.

Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given to the assessment and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 50% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
